title-group.article-title: How Important Was Silver? Some Evidence on Exchange Rate Fluctuations and Stock Returns in Colonial‐Era Asia*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2004 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We study the impact of silver price changes on stock returns from seven small open economies that switched among silver, gold, and paper money standards at different times between 1873 and 1939. Silver exposure is a priced factor in monthly equity returns. Changes in silver prices forecast realized monthly equity risk premiums, suggesting that expected risk premiums varied with the price of silver. Changes in silver prices forecast annual indicators of trade flows, global business cycles, and inflation. The evidence suggests how corporate profits and stock market risk premiums are linked to exchange rates, trade, economic activity, and inflation.

fn.p: We thank Kevin Chang, Eric Jacquier, Swee Sum Lam, Jim Lothian, Mike Montesano, Allen Reidy, Lan Truong, Ingrid Werner, and seminar participants at the University of Southern California, the University of California, Riverside, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, the 1997 Pacific Basin Finance Conference in Shanghai, the City University of Hong Kong, Ohio State University, the National University of Singapore, University of Maryland, Temple University, and New York University for helpful discussions, comments on earlier drafts, and other assistance. We thank Serena Agora‐Menyang, James Chan, Julie Goking, Gustavo Grullon, Blair Kanbar, Ayu Listiowati, Greg Loukedes, Hodaka Morita, Lillibeth Ortiz, Jane P. Wu, and Gul Yanmaz for research assistance. Special thanks to Peter Chung, Andrew Karolyi, René Stulz, and an anonymous referee for extensive, valuable comments. Contact the corresponding author, Warren Bailey, atwbb1@cornell.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Exchange rates are a principal preoccupation of international finance and economics. If consumers, corporations, and other economic entities cannot easily hedge against currency fluctuations, those fluctuations can affect aggregate consumption and wealth, export competitiveness and corporate profitability, and the overall course of economics and politics.If, by contrast, currency fluctuations are modest, can be hedged easily, or largely track inflation differentials, they may be of little consequence. Stock prices reflect the consensus estimate of the impact of exchange rate fluctuations and regime shifts on subsequent corporate earnings. Furthermore, stock prices represent a variety of industries that may respond to exchange rates differently and, thus, illustrate their effect on different sectors of an economy.

This study measures the impact of exchange rate fluctuations and exchange rate regime changes on equity values from China and other Asian economies from 1873 to 1939. We measure the importance of silver to the stock market both as a risk factor that earns an equity market risk premium and as an element of the information set that investors used to determine expected risk premiums. The seven economies we study abandoned a common currency, silver, for gold or paper at different times. The variety of regime‐switching events offers a unique opportunity to study the significance of exchange rate regime changes. The evolution of Asia’s common currency can be compared and contrasted with the decline of the Latin Monetary Union in nineteenth‐century Europe (Willis1901), the collapse of the Bretton Woods system in the early 1970s (Bartov, Bodnar, and Kaul1996), and the evolution of current European monetary arrangements.

The period that we study was a time of considerable international trade, free capital movements, and active global securities trading facilitated by overland and underwater telegraph lines.1As we shall discuss below, the existing evidence on links between stock markets and exchange rates is scant and often weak. Therefore, this period allows us to develop fresh evidence on the impact of exchange rates and exchange rate regime changes during a long time period that is comparable with the modern era in many ways. Furthermore, the seven economies that we study are analogous to the small, open “emerging markets,” which have generated much recent interest. Many sectors of China’s economy were geared to international trade, while European and U.S. colonies in Asia were dedicated to exporting agricultural and mineral commodities. We expect exchange rate fluctuations and changes in exchange rate regimes to have a particularly significant impact on these economies.

The article is organized as follows:Section IIdiscusses previous research, whileSection IIIexplains the contribution of this article given its unusual historical setting.Section IVoutlines the methodology and data set.Section Vpresents results on silver and stock returns and seeks explanations for the significant impact of silver that we document.Section VIis a summary and conclusion.

fn.p: The first transatlantic cable was laid in 1866, while the first cable connecting London to Shanghai was completed in 1871. See Garbade and Silber (1978), and Michie (1987).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Previous Research
sec.p: There is mixed evidence on associations between exchange rate fluctuations and returns on individual stocks or industry portfolios. For the United States for 1971–87, Jorion (1991) finds that returns for only five of 20 industry portfolios (textiles and apparel, chemicals, machinery, department stores, and other retail) are sensitive to changes in the value of the dollar. For individual firms, Jorion (1990) finds that only 15 of 287 U.S. firms have a significant exchange rate exposure during that same period. Choi and Prasad (1995) find that, for the period from 1978 to 1989, 61 of 409 U.S. firms have significant exposure. Bodnar and Gentry (1993) report related tests for Canada, Japan, and the United States, while He and Ng (1998) find that about 25% of 171 Japanese multinational firms show a significant exchange rate exposure. In a study of shares of traded and nontraded goods producers across six developed countries from 1975 to 1997, Griffin and Stulz (2001) find that the economic significance of exchange rates for stock returns is, at best, small. Interestingly, there is no evidence that the weak U.S. results are explained by hedging behavior (Bartov and Bodnar1994). Studies of specific industries sometimes detect a more significant impact of exchange rates on stock returns (Williamson2001). Studies of emerging markets suggest that exchange rates may reflect confidence or panic (Bailey and Chung1995).

If exchange rates affect stock returns, exposure to exchange rate risk can earn a risk premium in equity markets. In cross sections of national index returns converted to a common currency, the trade‐weighted value of the dollar appears to have a significant but secondary role as a priced risk factor (Ferson and Harvey1993; De Santis and Gerard1998). There is also evidence that the risk premium earned for holding foreign currency deposits is related to the U.S. stock market risk premium (Giovannini and Jorion1987; Korajczyk and Viallet1992). Some authors have searched for evidence of an equity market premium for exchange rate exposure in cross sections of individual stocks or industry portfolios of the same country. Jorion (1991) finds no evidence of an unconditional risk premium for exchange rate risk in the U.S. stock market: the size of a portfolio’s exposure to the value of the dollar does not appear to affect the return it pays to an investor. Beyond the United States, Choi, Hiraki, and Takezawa (1998) and He and Ng (1998) find some evidence of time‐varying equity premiums for exchange rate risk in Japan, while Bailey and Chung (1995) report a time‐varying risk premium for exposure to black market exchange rate fluctuations in the Mexican stock market.

The literature on exchange rate regimes tends to take a macroeconomic focus. In classic models like those of Krugman (1979) and Obstfeld (1988), the potential collapse of a pegged exchange rate regime is related to the country’s ability to support the exchange rate, the domestic interest rate, and the behavior of currency traders. In theory, a pegged regime can increase the volatility of domestic macroeconomic and financial indicators (Frenkel and Mussa (1980), particularly if the credibility of the peg is questionable (Flood and Hodrick1986). Empirical tests, however, suggest that the volatility of domestic money, output, and interest rates does not depend on whether the exchange rate regime is fixed or flexible (Flood and Rose1995).

There is little empirical evidence on associations between exchange rate regimes and stock returns. Comparing recent subperiods in the development of European exchange rate arrangements, Bodart and Reding (1999) find that increased exchange rate volatility is associated with a lower correlation between national equity markets. There is no evidence that changes in recent European exchange rate regimes affect stock return volatility. Bartov et al. (1996) find that the systematic and total return volatility of U.S. multinational firms is larger during a period of increased exchange rate volatility. Their interesting results are based on a single regime change event, the breakdown of the Bretton Woods agreement in 1973. Hardouvelis, Malliaropulos, and Priestley (1999) report that the risk‐return relationship across European equity markets has converged as the 1999 adoption of the Euro approached.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Asian Colonial Monetary Regimes
sec.p: The previous discussion indicates that the amount of research on exchange rates and stock returns is limited, and the results are often weak. A significant problem is the dearth of abrupt exchange rate regime changes for the U.S. economy and other economies with good histories of stock market data. Therefore, the adoption and, in some cases, abandonment of Western Europe’s Exchange Rate Mechanism, the recent inauguration of the euro, and the likely extension of the euro area to other countries are important cases for continuing study.

The monetary history of Asia from the mid‐nineteenth century to World War II substantially extends the history of exchange rate changes and regime‐shift events available for research. Much as the euro is expected to grow in importance today, silver grew to play a central role in the workings of the colonial Asian economies. This common currency was abandoned at different times by different economies, leading to gold and, eventually, paper money standards across the region. Therefore, the primary contribution of this article is to exploit the availability of stock market data from this long period that experienced many monetary regime change events to understand further the impact of changing currency values and standards on stock returns.

How did silver evolve into Asia’s common currency? As China opened to trade several hundred years ago, the Chinese had little interest in Western products, so it was necessary to bring hard currency to Chinese ports to exchange for tea, silks, porcelain, and other commodities in high demand in the West.2China’s traditional monetary system relied on silver bullion, so foreign traders typically paid for Chinese products with silver coins that were minted in great quantity from Mexican and Peruvian silver. As trade grew, foreign silver coins gained wide acceptance in China’s domestic commerce as well.3Retail prices and legal contracts were denominated in silver, measured in terms of the Chinese ounce known as thetaelorliang(), and equal to slightly more than one English ounce. Spanish and Mexican silver dollars were accepted as payment by weight or, in some cities, directly, as prices were quoted in Mexican dollars. Silver trade coins were produced by Imperial and Republican China, its provinces, Japan, and principal colonial powers into the twentieth century.4The use of silver coins spread from early European toeholds to other economies throughout East and Southeast Asia.

The workings of a silver standard were often chaotic. In China, for example, there was no legal currency until the standard silver dollar of exact weight and fineness was declared in April 1933. Silver bullion, various coins, and banknotes circulated side by side, while the system of weights and measures for silver differed from city to city. A typical Shanghai newspaper listed different exchange rates for sight drafts, forward drafts, credits, bills, and telegraph transfers to London, Paris, and other centers. There were also prices for silver bullion, Mexican dollars, and older Spanish dollars that were well known and therefore particularly acceptable in transactions with more traditional local customers and business partners. Furthermore, “clean” dollars typically sold at a premium to coins that had been defaced, tested, or “chopped” by local merchants. Coins competed with well‐accepted banknotes of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank and other private issuers. The convenience of banknotes sometimes earned a premium above silver (King1988a) that was, at times, significant prior to the 1880s (King1965,1988b). Other Asian countries and territories had similar experiences. British Malaya, for example, sanctioned Mexican and other foreign silver coins as legal tender into the early twentieth century.

The value of silver was often influenced by events far from Asian shores. New discoveries of silver in Mexico, Peru, and the United States along with sales of silver by countries adopting the gold standard decreased the price of the white metal.5Political pressure by senators from mining areas of the United States had, at times, led the U.S. government to adopt massive silver purchase programs that increased the price of silver.

There are many references to the implications of silver fluctuations for colonial‐era Asian businesses. Chiang (1966) notes that cheap silver enhanced Malaya’s export competitiveness during that colony’s silver period. Exports of Indochina’s rubber increased with decreases in the value of the silverpiastre(Murray1980), while rubber production in gold‐standard Netherlands Indies was adversely affected by cheap silver. Netherlands Indies manufacturers suffered an influx of imported textiles and other consumer products when Britain and Japan devalued their currencies and detached them from gold in 1931 (Furnivall1944). Friedman and Schwartz (1960) suggest that low silver prices in the late 1920s and early 1930s helped boost China’s exports and shielded its economy from the beginnings of the Great Depression.

Table 1summarizes the currency regimes in force during the period we study. China remained on silver continuously until November 1935 (Shen1941), but other Asian countries and territories switched among silver, gold, and paper standards at various times in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.6Between 1877 and 1936, there are four switches from silver to gold, two from silver to paper, and five from gold to paper. This accounting excludes temporary suspensions of gold in favor of paper around the time of World War I, as there were many confounding economic and political developments at that time. Furthermore, we exclude Japan’s switch from silver to gold in 1897 because Japanese stock market records do not extend far enough into the past to span that event. Table 1

Note.—The table indicates monetary standards in force during the period we study. “Pegged” refers to a variety of arrangements by which the value of the colonial currency was related to the home country currency. Among other countries that we do not study, India switched to gold in June 1893 and Siam in November 1902. Mexico, the source of metal for billions of “pieces of eight,” abandoned silver for gold in 1905.

Why was silver abandoned? The Japanese followed the Europeans, who had abandoned silver after many chaotic decades in which both gold and silver were legal tender but fluctuated widely in value. In China, the government claimed that expensive silver in the early 1930s was throttling export competitiveness and causing a drain of money from the country. In British Malaya and French Indochina earlier in the century, exporters enjoyed competitiveness from cheap silver. However, government officials and other expatriates objected to the declining gold value of their salaries and assets, while fluctuations in the value of silver were a source of general discontent in the business community. These constituencies prevailed in driving their colonial economies off silver.

fn.p: Foreign traders also brought opium to Chinese ports to facilitate trade (see Bailey and Truong2001).
Only small retail transactions were conducted with copper coins known ascash(see King1965).

From the first coins struck in 1537 to the last Mexican production in 1903, almost 4 billion Spanish and Mexican dollars were struck. Hundreds of millions of additional silver trade coins were produced by Japan, Britain, France, and the United States to facilitate Asian trade. See Willem (1959), Chiang (1966), and Sandrock (1995).

Germany, the Netherlands, and the Scandinavian countries abandoned silver in 1871, while large silver deposits were discovered in Nevada in 1873. The U.S. silver purchase programs were initiated or modified by the Bland‐Allison Act (1878), the Sherman Silver Purchase Act (1890), and the Silver Purchase Act of 1934 (see Leavens1939). Friedman (1992) discusses the possibility that the U.S. silver purchase program initiated in 1934 overvalued silver, crippled Chinese export competitiveness, and drove China off silver. Subsequent inflation may even have hastened the fall of China to communism.

We do not distinguish between a gold standard where gold coin is literally in circulation and a gold exchange standard where the currency is maintained at par with a gold‐standard currency of another country and, thus, is indirectly convertible into gold coin (see Wagel1914). For details of the currency regimes, see Vissering (1920), Cassel (1922), League of Nations (1937), Robequain (1939), Touzet (1939), Allen and Donnithorne (1957), Friedman and Schwartz (1960), Shinjo (1962), Chiang (1966), King (1988a), Friedman (1990), and van der Berg (1996).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Methodology
sec.p:
We follow the three‐pass procedure of Ferson and Harvey (1991) adapted from the classic two‐pass procedure of Fama and MacBeth (1973).10First, we estimate time series regressions of realized stock portfolio excess returns on three risk factors: the silver price change, the silver regime slope dummy, and the global stock index excess return, plus an intercept. The silver regime slope dummy equals the silver price change during months when the home country of theith portfolio is on the silver standard and zero otherwise:
This produces an estimate of the risk exposure vector, β i , for theith portfolio. The time series regression is estimated individually for each portfolio return series in the sample.

Third, we characterize the behavior of the risk premium series (and the orthogonal portfolio return series) produced at the second stage. We estimate time‐series regressions of each risk premium series on lagged values of the silver price change, the global stock index excess return, the U.K. interest rate, and the growth in value of U.S. and U.K. imports and exports. These lagged factors proxy for the information, Ω t , that investors use to formulate expected stock returns. Many previous authors have employed similar factors to reflect the state of financial markets, the economy, monetary policy, and other information that investors use to form expected risk premiums. Statistically significant regression slope coefficients are consistent with the presence of time‐varying expected risk premiums (as ineq. [1]) in the estimated realized risk premiums produced byequation (3).11

We examine several facets of the results of the third stage of the empirical procedure. If there is a stock market risk premium for exposure to silver, the lagged information variables should have significant power to forecast the realized risk premium series for silver and the silver regime slope dummy. If silver is an element of the information set that investors use to formulate expected risk premiums, lagged silver should have significant power to forecast realized risk premiums for silver, the silver regime slope dummy, and perhaps even the global stock index. Finally, there should be no power to forecast the realized return on the orthogonal portfolio: the realized orthogonal return series is pure noise if our pricing model is correct and our set of risk factors is complete.

fn.p: See, e.g., Ferson (1990), and Ferson and Harvey (1991).
Adler and Dumas (1983) motivate the use of exchange rate terms in an asset pricing model.
The risk exposures can vary through time as well.
We are unable to implement a more efficient one‐pass procedure because of missing values and different lengths of data series among the stock returns.

Although the realized risk premiums are generated at the second stage, they are used as dependent variables rather than regressors in the third stage and, thus, do not induce the classical errors‐in‐variables problem in the third stage. To the extent that the realized risk premium returns measure the true risk premiums with noise, standard errors of coefficients are enlarged, and the regressions are biased against significance.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: There are, to our knowledge, no Asian stock market databases beyond the Emerging Stock Markets database of the World Bank’s International Finance Corporation and the Pacific Basin Capital Markets Research Center tapes maintained by this center at the University of Rhode Island.12Both of these sources extend back to the 1970s at the earliest. Thus, our initial task was to build a database from scratch.

Stock prices. End‐of‐month stock prices were collected from principal national, colonial, or metropolitan newspapers. Quotes for Netherlands Indies from prior to 1912 are from the Amsterdam stock market, all French Indochina quotes are in francs from the Paris market, and all other quotes come from Asian newspapers.13See theappendixfor a detailed description of the newspapers and other sources from which data were extracted. Stock prices are either closing transactions or bid‐offer midpoints from organized or over‐the‐counter markets. The firms selected are quoted regularly, have relatively large capitalization, and represent leading industries. While only a handful of companies are collected from each market, they are typically the largest firms, which represent much of the total market capitalization and, in many cases, explicitly owned partial stakes in many other listed firms.Table 2summarizes company names and the manner in which they have been grouped into industry portfolios. Data on dividends, ex dividend dates, and shares outstanding were published only irregularly and, therefore, were not collected. All stock prices are translated into pounds using end‐of‐month exchange rates also collected from these newspapers. Exchange rates are closing or midpoint quotes for bills on London or telegraphic transfers to London. Table 2

Note.—End‐of‐month stock prices were collected from colonial or metropolitan newspapers. Pre‐1912 quotes for Netherlands Indies are from Amsterdam, while all French Indochina quotes are from Paris. All other quotes come from organized or over‐the‐counter markets in Asia. The firms selected are quoted regularly, have relatively large capitalization, and represent leading industries. Except where noted, each company has data spanning the years indicated in the column heading. The table does not indicate the frequency of missing observations because of market closures during the World War I or other disturbances, corporate reorganization, infrequent trading, or missing newspapers. Missing observations are especially severe for Japan.

The sample period is December 1872 through August 1939. Stock data are almost entirely absent prior to that time, while all markets were disrupted and eventually shut because of the outbreak of war in Europe in September 1939.Table 2does not attempt to describe the frequency of missing observations or the many events leading to the disappearance of individual companies or closure of entire markets. For example, the Tanjong Pagar Dock Company was nationalized in 1905 by the colonial government (Bogaars1956), while Malayan tin and rubber companies blossomed with commodity price booms and then vanished in liquidation or reorganization when commodity prices fell (Wong1965; Pahang Consolidated Co.1966). Many markets closed during World War I (1914–18), the 1925 general strike in China, and other disturbances. Data for French Indochina and the Philippines begin relatively late because there was no active stock trading earlier.

Additionally,table 2does not indicate the cross‐listing of securities across Asia or with the London stock market. Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank was listed continuously in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and London. Spot checks indicate that stock prices are very similar across the markets after accounting for different currencies of quotation. This is not surprising given the absence of barriers to arbitrage, particularly the availability of telegraph communications, throughout our sample period. In Hong Kong, some of the larger Shanghai stocks (EWO Cotton, Shanghai Dock, Shanghai Land) were often quoted, as was one of our Malayan tin mines, Tronoh. Hong Kong companies (Hong Kong Land, Whampoa, Wharf) were usually quoted in Shanghai. Hong Kong and China Gas was sometimes quoted in London, and, at points during commodity booms, some Malayan tin and rubber shares were traded in London as well. Again, we found no significant gaps in pricing across markets.

The sample firms are fairly representative of the economies of the countries and territories covered. For French Indochina, for example, the Portland Cement factory and the major coal producer, Charbonnages du Tonkin, represent the economy of Tonkin in the north, while the rubber estates represent the economy of Cochinchina in the south (Murray1980). The absence of plantation shares from the Philippines is consistent with the concentration of corporate capital in agricultural processing rather than agricultural production (Robequain1954). Cooperative and competitive relationships between firms are also reflected in the sample. Straits Trading, for example, was formed in 1886, leased facilities from Tanjong Pagar Dock in 1887, and employed Straits Steamship to transport tin ore, coal, and tin ingots. Jelebu Mining, Pahang Consolidated, and the other British Malayan tin mines in our sample were major suppliers of tin ore to Straits Trading and its rival, Eastern Smelting (Tregonning1963). Koninklijke Paketvart was founded in 1888 to compete with Straits Steamship and other British firms that dominated the shipping business in the Netherlands Indies (Furnivall1944).

Silver. To measure the impact of silver on stock returns, we use changes in the price of silver in London as the silver factor in our empirical tests. It was the benchmark for determining exchange rates throughout the period we study, and telegraph lines connecting London to major Asian cities permitted the current London silver quote to be disseminated immediately throughout Asia.Figure 1displays monthly prices, in U.K. pence per ounce, of silver at London. The series displays significant volatility, trends, and jumps during our sample period. Fig. 1.—
The plot shows the end of month price of silver in London in pence per ounce

Global stock index. We collect monthly returns on British and U.S. stock indexes to construct a global equity risk factor. For Britain, we use a stock index series spliced from the London and Cambridge Economic Service’sThe British Economy Key Statistics(through 1921) andBanker’s Monthly(1922 on).14For the United States, we combine the series constructed by Schwert (1990) through 1925 with the Center for Research in Security Prices value‐weighted index that starts on December 1925. We translate the U.S. index returns to pounds and construct an equally weighted index of British and U.S. index returns to serve as our global stock index return series. Ideally, we should like to have the equivalent of the Morgan Stanley Capital International world index, but such a series is not available to our knowledge.

fn.p: Recently, Goetzmann and Jorion (1999) uncovered stock price indexes from 1921 to World War II for several of the countries in our sample. Their source is League of Nations publications.
A stock exchange was proposed for Saigon in 1926 but never developed (Simoni1929).
We thank Tim Opler for providing this data.
Straits Settlements was the crown colony that comprised Malacca, Penang, Singapore, and a few other small parts of British Malaya.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Results
sec.p: We compute stock returns using log‐differences of stock prices converted to pounds and then subtract a short‐term U.K. interest rate (the “open market rate of discount at London”) to yield excess returns. Individual stock price return series are then aggregated into equally weighted industry portfolios following the classifications intable 2. Not all industries are observable for all economies. Furthermore, there are some cases where the industry portfolio consists of a single prominent firm.16We also construct equally weighted national indexes of all sample company returns for each country and territory.

fn.p: While the number of firms is small, these firms often represented a broad cross‐section of the local economy. Nederlandse Indies Handelsbank, e.g., held stakes in agricultural firms, tin mines, and the Netherlands Indies Spoorweg (railway) in addition to functioning as a conventional bank. In the French territories, a 1900 decree allowed Banque de l’Indochine to invest in shares of other companies, while Societe Financiere des Caoutchoucs established and retained stakes in many rubber plantations, including Terres Rouges (Murray1980). In contrast, agriculture and mining in British Malaya did not evolve around large banks or holding companies: British Malayan “agency houses” evolved from merchant firms to firms providing managerial expertise and other assistance, but they did not function as banks or holding companies (Allen and Donnithorne1957).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Summary Statistics
sec.p:
Table 3presents summary statistics on the returns of the 31 industry portfolios; log‐differences of silver, the global index, and the U.K. and U.S. trade measure; and the U.K. short‐term interest rate. The variety of lengths of data across portfolio series is evident, with Shanghai Ports being the longest (795 months) and Japan Mining the shortest (53 months). The volatility of returns varies widely, with large Netherlands Indies agricultural and financial conglomerates displaying volatility only one‐third or one‐quarter that of natural resource industries like mining and rubber. Compared with the summary statistics in Bekaert and Harvey (1997), the volatilities of Asian colonial stock returns are lower than typical modern emerging markets. The global stock index displays positive serial correlation at the first lag, as is typically found in modern stock index returns, including the emerging markets studied by Bekaert and Harvey (1997). Serial correlation ranges from positive to negative across the industry portfolios. Skewness is comparable in Asian colonial markets and modern emerging markets, while kurtosis is sometimes much larger in colonial times. Table 3

There are two particularly notable aspects to the average returns earned by the portfolios. First, the global index has positive average price growth during the period. Most of the other portfolios have negative price growth resulting from silver price declines in the 1920s, currency devaluations as metallic standards were abandoned, and depressed economic conditions at the end of the sample period. Note also that these are price‐only portfolio returns and do not include dividends. Second, many of the firms in the better‐performing portfolios exist to this day and continue to trade actively on stock markets under their original names. Both facts are suggestive of the survivorship issues discussed by Goetzmann and Jorion (1999). With a few exceptions, colonial Asian stocks offered investors a bumpy and unsatisfying ride relative to U.S. and U.K. stocks.

Table 4presents return correlations between country stock index portfolios (created from equally weighting the companies in the sample) and between the risk factors and information variables. Intable 4, panel A, there are some sensible associations among the national stock indexes. British Malaya, French Indochina, and Netherlands Indies show significant cross‐correlation, perhaps because of their common exposure to the prices of tin, rubber, and other crops and minerals. Hong Kong and Shanghai are strongly correlated, as might be expected given their connections to the Chinese economy. However, the cross‐country correlations are much lower than what is typically observed between developed economies in the 1980s and 1990s, although they parallel Harvey (1995) and Bekaert and Harvey (1997) in showing that modern emerging markets are typically more sensitive to idiosyncratic, rather than common, influences. Intable 4, panel B, it is notable that silver and global indexes are contemporaneously uncorrelated while lags of silver are correlated with the global index. The U.K. short‐term interest rate is negatively correlated with subsequent global stock index returns and positively correlated with concurrent U.K. and U.S. trade growth. Low or insignificant correlations among these variables suggest that multicollinearity will not be a problem in our empirical tests. Table 4

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Did Exposure to Exchange Rates Earn a Premium in the Stock Markets?
sec.p: In thissubsection, we present and discuss the results of the three‐stage estimation of the asset pricing model,equation (1). The application of any asset‐pricing model to our data is tentative for at least two reasons. First, our return series are capital gains only because we could not obtain consistent records on dividends and ex‐dividend dates. This can affect results significantly if the dividend component of total returns is large and varies substantially through time.17Second, our stock returns data display patterns of missing observations that vary across industries, thus preventing us from employing more efficient one‐pass econometric procedures.

Table 5presents results of the first stage of the procedure, regressions of stock returns on log‐differences of the silver price, the silver regime slope dummy, and log differences of the global stock index.18The “silver regime slope dummy” term distinguishes the impact of silver during the period when the particular region was on silver. Eight of the 31 portfolios show a significant association with the silver price change series. Nine of 31 portfolios show a significant association with the silver exposure slope dummy, suggesting that the sensitivity to silver was different in the period when the underlying economy was on silver. Althoughtable 5indicates that only a minority of portfolios displays a significant exposure to silver, previous authors have found this sufficient to detect statistically significant risk premiums in related contexts.19 Table 5also reports slope coefficients, or “betas,” on the global stock index return. There are several portfolios from French Indochina that display large global betas. For the most part, however, the stock sensitivities to this factor are small. Only about half of the portfolios display a significant slope for the global stock index factor. Table 5

Table 6reports third‐pass regression estimates for each of the realized risk premium series and for the return on the orthogonal portfolio. The table also reports the time‐series average of each series. Average realized risk premiums are dwarfed by their standard errors and are indistinguishable from zero. Expected risk premiums are implied by fitted regression values and suggest an economically significant average expected risk premium for silver exposure as follows: the sum of the estimated intercept and products of slope coefficients times the average values of the lagged variables (table 3) indicates a monthly expected risk premium of about 2.5% for unit exposure to silver. Significant estimated silver exposures of stock portfolios (table 5) range from about −0.35 to 0.46. Multiplying by 2.5% implies expected silver risk premiums ranging from −0.8% to 1.15% per month for these portfolios. Table 6

Note.—The table reports the third and final stage of our procedure. The first stage is time‐series regressions of industry portfolio excess returns on the silver price change, the silver regime slope dummy, and the global stock index excess return to produce estimated risk exposure (reported intable 5). The second stage is cross‐sectional regressions of industry portfolio excess returns on the estimated risk exposures to produce estimated ex post risk premiums for exposure to silver, silver regime slope dummy, and global stock index, plus returns on a portfolio with no exposure to any factor (see Fama and MacBeth1973). The third stage is time‐series regressions of the estimated risk premiums on lags of silver, global stock, money market, and world economic activity indicators. Forecast power over the ex post risk premiums is consistent with time‐varying ex ante risk premiums (see Ferson and Harvey1991). Thet‐statistics reported beneath each coefficient estimate are adjusted for serial correlation and heteroskedasticity following White (1980) and Newey and West (1987). Each regression uses 795 observations from January 1873 to August 1939.

The regression results themselves are consistent with the presence of time‐varying expected risk premiums in the estimated‐realized risk premium series. Although theR 2coefficients are small, they are not radically different from what has been reported in studies of modern stock markets.20The regression for the silver risk premium has an adjustedR 2of almost 5% and significant negative slope coefficients on lags of silver and the U.K. interest rate. Intuitively, this means that an increase in the value of silver tends to predict a lower stock market risk premium for silver exposure during the next month. An increase in the U.K. interest rate tends to predict a lower stock market risk premium for silver exposure as well.21Higher silver also tends to predict lower stock market risk premiums for exposure to the silver regime and global index factors. Higher growth in aggregate U.K. and U.S. trade tends to predict a marginally higher stock market risk premium for silver and a significantly higher stock market risk premium for the silver regime slope dummy factor. Collectively, these results suggest that silver was a significant risk factor for Asian stock returns and a significant state variable that global investors included in their forecasts of expected returns and the course of the global economy.

There is also strong evidence that increases in silver (and the global stock index) forecast changes in the return on the orthogonal “zero beta” portfolio. Byequation (1), a portfolio with no risk exposures is pure noise and is not a priced risk, if the model is correct and if we have implemented it with the correct factors and risk exposures.22This portfolio represents the impact of dividends that we cannot measure, risk premiums for macroeconomic risks that we have not identified or included in the procedure, and other factors missing from the model. Significant zero beta portfolio returns are not unique to our study and appear in many classic tests of domestic asset pricing models over U.S. data.23This indicates that our model and set of risk factors are incomplete. We discuss the identity of potential missing factors inSection VI.

fn.p: See Stambaugh (1983).

Following Jorion (1991), we orthogonalize silver price changes over the global stock index returns and use the resulting residual in subsequent empirical tests. This does not induce an errors‐in‐variables problem since the generated regressor is an unlagged residual (see Pagan1984,1986).
See, e.g., Choi et al. (1998) and He and Ng (1998) for on time‐varying equity premiums for exchange rate risk in modern Japan.
Ferson and Harvey (1991) report, in their table 6, adjustedR 2s ranging from 0% to 14%.
Ferson and Harvey (1991) find that the U.S. interest rate is negatively correlated with subsequent U.S. equity risk premiums measured from 1964 to 1986.

We also attempted to estimate risk exposures using two other methods: 60‐month rolling regressions and a conditional process in which risk exposures depend on lagged information variables (Ferson and Harvey1991,1993). However, the rolling regression process produced far fewer significant exposures (and many missing observations) than the constant exposures reported intable 5. The conditional process produced some evidence that risk exposures vary through time. Both sets of risk exposures produced insignificant risk premium results at the third stage, perhaps because of missing data and the potential for parameter estimates to reflect economically meaningless artifacts of the data.
See, e.g., Black, Jensen, and Scholes (1972), and Gibbons (1982).

sec.label: C.
sec.title: What Explains the Significance of Silver?
sec.p: It is evident that silver was a significant risk factor that earned a risk premium in colonial Asian stock markets. Furthermore, silver had power to forecast the risk premiums for the broad macroeconomic forces that affect company profitability and stock returns. What is the source and nature of the significance of silver for stock returns? Given the era we study, there are severe limitations to the company and macroeconomic data available to explore this question. Nonetheless, we offer some additional discussion and evidence as follows: we seek both firm specific and macroeconomic explanations.

The pound value of silver is the exchange rate between the gold‐standard and silver‐standard economies. It can be thought of as having both real and nominal components.Figure 2plots the cumulative deviations of the value of China’s currency in terms of the gold‐standard currencies of Netherlands Indies and the United Kingdom. It is evident that exchange rates deviate substantially from Purchasing Power Parity.24If Purchasing Power Parity violations induce changes in patterns of international competitiveness, we should see specific patterns in the silver and silver regime slope dummy risk exposures estimated for the first stage of our empirical procedure, the risk exposure estimates reported intable 5. Specifically, returns on shares of export (import) industries should be negatively (positively) correlated with changes in the value of the home currency. Furthermore, exposure to the value of silver should change as a country or territory changes its currency standard. Fig. 2.—
The plot shows the cumulative yearly purchasing power parity deviations for the Netherlands Indies guilders per Chinese silver dollar, and British pounds per Chinese silver dollar exchange rates. The guilder and pound were on gold during all but 11 years of our sample period. The purchasing power parity deviation equals the rate of change of the value of the Chinese dollar minus the difference between Chinese and foreign wholesale price inflation. Values greater than one indicate that the Chinese currency is overvalued relative to the other currency. The solid line is for N. I. guilders; the dotted line is for U.K. pounds.

Intable 5, eight of the 31 portfolios show a significant association with the silver price change series. For example, a 1% increase in the pound value of silver is associated with a significant 0.072% increase in the pound value of Netherlands Indies Banking and Insurance shares. This is consistent with increased export competitiveness in gold‐standard Netherlands Indies at times of expensive silver. Similar results for Philippine banking and insurance, food, and mining are consistent with the export competitiveness story and the gold standard in that country. While competitiveness explanations are sensible and motivate a role for silver in stock pricing, only a minority of portfolios displays a significant slope coefficient on silver.

Table 5also reports slope coefficients on the “silver regime slope dummy” term to isolate the differential effect of silver when the particular country was on the silver standard. Nine of 31 portfolios show a significant association with the silver exposure slope dummy, suggesting that the sensitivity to silver was different in the period when the underlying economy was on silver. Four British Malaya portfolios are sensitive to the value of silver only when that territory was on the silver standard. In support of the export competitiveness story, the British Malaya Commercial and Industrial portfolio has a positive loading on the silver regime slope. This is sensible as the firms comprising this portfolio produced or retailed consumer products, and high silver would have lowered the cost of imported raw materials and finished goods. Positive exposures to the silver regime dummy for British Malaya Mining, Ports, and Transport seem counterintuitive, as expensive silver should dampen export activity. As we will discuss below, expensive silver may be associated with global economic expansion that benefited exports. The same arguments may be advanced for the Shanghai Commercial and Industrial portfolio that consists of an export‐oriented textile mill.

Two portfolios, French Indochina Commercial and Industrial and Hong Kong Real Estate, display significantly negative slopes on silver and significantly positive slopes on the “silver regime slope dummy” term. Given the size of the coefficients, this means that exposure to silver was positive during the period (through 1930 for French Indochina and through 1935 for Hong Kong) that the local economy was on silver and negative afterward. While this is strongly consistent with the notion that a change in the currency regime induces a change in stock return exposures to silver, it is again not straightforward to offer an intuitive explanation. Perhaps a positive correlation of silver with global economic activity explains the relationship prior to the 1930s, while hedging demand for silver during the period of political and economic uncertainty in the 1930s explains the relationship afterward.

On balance, combining firm‐specific characteristics (such as whether a firm is an exporter or importer) and the export competitiveness story offers at best a weak explanation for the importance of silver to stock returns. Note, however, that we have expressed all portfolio returns in pounds so that the exchange rate exposures intable 5reflect the point of view of an investor in a gold‐standard area like the United Kingdom or the United States. The perceived exposures would be quite different for an investor with silver as her numeraire. Consider, for example, the Hong Kong Banking and Insurance portfolio during the period when Hong Kong was on silver. When the pound value of silver increases by 1%, the table shows that a gold‐standard investor perceives a statistically insignificant decline of about 0.1924% in the pound value of the portfolio (the sum of coefficients on silver and silver slope dummy). However, a silver numeraire investor also perceives a 1% decline in the value of the pound at the time that silver appreciates by 1%, in addition to the decline in the pound value of the portfolio. Any silver exposure less than unity in pound terms implies a loss of value in silver terms.

The firm‐specific impact of silver price changes is only one tack we can take to understand why silver was significant to stock returns during this era. A real change in the price of silver can induce changes in aggregate international trade and economic activity generally or can result from changes in demand for silver money and objects that are positively correlated with changes in global economic activity. If changes in flows of orders, production, and goods shipped are gradual, changes in the price of silver can forecast changes in the volume and direction of international trade and economic activity. Furthermore, a change in the price of silver also reflects expected changes in the price level, even if Purchasing Power Parity does not completely explain changes in the value of silver. Therefore, changes in the price of silver may also forecast inflation. To test these propositions, we obtain data on trade and wholesale price levels. Unfortunately, such data are only available on an annual basis and are limited by the quality of Asian colonial economic reports and other data sources.Table 7reports regressions of annual changes in trade and price levels on annual changes in the silver price. Table 7, panel A, assesses silver’s forecast power over imports and exports for the three economies for which we were able to obtain annual trade data. Netherlands Indies and Straits Settlements switched from silver to gold during the time period that the trade data are available, so we also include a slope dummy term to isolate the differential effect during the silver regime. There are a number of interesting results intable 7. There is no power to explain Chinese imports, perhaps because the demand for imported luxury products was price inelastic or matched by inflows of capital. However, there is forecast power over exports: a 1% increase in the pound value of silver in 1 year is associated with a 0.15% decline in Chinese exports the following year. During the silver‐standard period in the Netherlands Indies, exports are also significantly negatively associated with previous increases in the pound value of silver. It is more difficult to explain why Netherlands Indies imports tend to rise with silver. In the Straits Settlements, both export and import growth are predicted by increases in the value of silver, while the slope dummy term indicates that both exports and imports decline with high silver during the silver‐regime period. This makes sense if a cheap currency increases competitiveness, drives up exports, and gives consumers more income with which to purchase imports.

The final row oftable 7, panel A, indicates that silver has very substantial forecast power over aggregate U.K. and U.S. trade, our proxy for global economic activity. Specifically, silver prices rise in advance of an increase in global activity, perhaps because demand for silver rises with the global economy. The adjustedR 2is over 40%. This strong association offers an explanation for the seemingly counterintuitive results on portfolio risk exposures intable 5and imports and exports earlier in the panel: silver is strongly correlated with global economic activity, which in turn drives exports, activity in ports and shipping, and consumer spending in an economy like British Malaya. Furthermore, this reasoning also leads to an explanation for the finding intable 6that increases in the price of silver tend to predict decreases in silver and global index risk premiums in the stock market. A silver price increase forecasts an increase in economic activity, and, as previous authors have found, when times are good, risk premiums tend to shrink (Fama and French1989; Chen1991; Ferson and Harvey1991). On balance,table 7, panel A, suggests that part of the predictive power of silver for stock market risk premiums relates to the ability of silver to predict Asian trade flows and global economic activity, which in turn affect local economic activity, corporate profits, and stock returns.

Table 7, panel B, examines the ability of silver price changes to predict inflation. We include a contemporaneous silver price change to recognize the potential contemporaneous relation between inflation and the silver exchange rate given the theory of Purchasing Power Parity, in addition to the forecasting effect for which we are looking. Except for China, the lagged annual silver price change displays significant forecast power over wholesale price inflation. It is unclear whether investors set the price of silver as they attempt to hedge against anticipated inflation or whether increases in the price of silver cause inflation. For our purposes, it is sufficient to say that the forecast power of silver over stock risk premiums is, in part, explained by the power of silver to forecast inflation. This also suggests a plausible explanation for the power of silver to forecast the return on the orthogonal portfolio, as reported intable 6: since we lack monthly data on inflation from this era, the orthogonal portfolio returns can capture an equity market premium for inflation risk.25

fn.p: We also regressed percent changes in the pound value of silver on the spread between Chinese and Netherlands Indies inflation. An adjustedR 2of 39.1% and slope coefficient (SE) of 0.8687 (0.1319) confirm that inflation differentials were an important but not exclusive determinant of the relative values of silver and gold currencies in the region. See Lothian (1991) and Lothian and Taylor (1996) for evidence that purchasing power parity for other currencies (the dollar, pound, franc, and yen) was, at best, valid only in the long run during the period we study. Also see evidence and discussions in Jamieson (1893).
Indeed, Ferson and Harvey (1991, n. 27) report that “zero beta” portfolio returns seem similar to the inflation risk premiums that they are able to measure directly with monthly U.S. data.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Summary and Conclusions
sec.p: We have exploited the availability of new data and a sequence of exchange rate regime changes to understand further the impact of changing currency values and changing currency standards on stock returns. We document a number of facets of the relationship between silver exchange rates and colonial Asian stock prices during the period 1873–1939. There is evidence of a stock market risk premium for silver exposure and a role for silver as one of the state variables investors used to determine expected risk premiums in the stock market. Several industries exhibit significant exposures to ups and downs in the value of silver, which is consistent with their roles as exporters or importers and a competitiveness interpretation of exchange rate changes. On an annual basis, silver has forecast power over both real and nominal economic indicators such as local and global trade and price levels. The impact of silver in the stock market relates in part to its ability to forecast changes in real economic variables like trade and economic growth and changes in inflation. The negative relationship between silver price changes and subsequent equity market risk premiums is particularly compelling as it is consistent with published findings that U.S. equity market risk premiums tend to recede during economic upturns and rise during downturns.

How do these results contribute to the existing literature on stock returns and exchange rates? We confirm that it is not straightforward to infer a competitiveness story from regressions of (individual or industry portfolio) stock returns on exchange rate changes, although this is clearly part of the story. As noted by Jorion (1991), exchange rate changes reflect changes in a variety of economic and monetary conditions. Our results on the ability of silver to predict changes in macroeconomic indicators suggest that exchange rates affect stock markets through broad macroeconomic channels. Future researchers may find it fruitful to trace the links between stock returns, exchange rates, and risk premiums to macroeconomic conditions, as authors like Chen (1991) and Ferson and Harvey (1991) have done to explain U.S. stock returns in a strictly domestic context.

This study of rather old stock price data is subject to some limitations. We have no information on the liquidity or rationality of the markets from which the stock prices are drawn. Lacking more detailed information on the firms, we cannot speculate with greater precision about the determinants of the reactions to exchange rates we have documented. The absence of higher frequency macroeconomic data limits our ability to ascribe the significance of silver to more fundamental economic forces like inflation. It may also be the case that the openness of these economies, the lack of demand for protection by businesses or workers, and other aspects of these largely unregulated economies allowed companies to adjust prices, wages, and other costs relatively easily in the face of seemingly significant exchange rate developments.

Regardless of these shortcomings, we get a good deal of evidence about the importance of exchange rates and exchange rate regimes for equity markets. Perhaps the strongest conclusion we can draw from these results is that the novel data prove their usefulness in understanding the forces that link equity markets and broader economic conditions.
